id_1.input:
CLINTON: "which may prove to be an intelligence benefit
we've got to do everything we can to vacuum up intelligence from Europe, from the Middle East
That means we've got to work more closely with our allies, and that's something that Donald has been very dismissive of
We're working with NATO, the longest military alliance in the history of the world, to really turn our attention to terrorism
We're working with our friends in the Middle East, many of which, as you know, are Muslim majority nations
Donald has consistently insulted Muslims abroad, Muslims at home, when we need to be cooperating with Muslim nations and with the American Muslim community
They're on the front lines
They can provide information to us that we might not get anywhere else
They need to have close working cooperation with law enforcement in these communities, not be alienated and pushed away as some of Donald's rhetoric, unfortunately, has led to"

cqs.cq: Are there other factors in this particular case that could have interfered with the event of NATO and Muslim nations providing the necessary intelligence to counter terrorism, given that intelligence sharing has historically been effective in certain contexts, but also faced challenges due to various factors such as language barriers, cultural differences, and conflicting interests?
Is CLINTON's claim that "Donald has consistently insulted Muslims abroad, Muslims at home" consistent with what other experts in the field of international relations and diplomacy say?

Are there differences between Clinton's approach to international cooperation and Trump's approach that would tend to undermine the force of the similarity cited, given that both approaches aim to combat terrorism, but Trump's approach has been criticized for being more isolationist and divisive?

Is it practically possible for Clinton to achieve her proposed approach of "working more closely with our allies" and "cooperating with Muslim nations and the American Muslim community" if Donald's rhetoric continues to alienate and push them away?

id_2.input:
CLINTON: "If you help create the profits , you should be able to share in them , not just the executives at the top
I want us to do more to support people who are struggling to balance family and work
I 've heard from so many of you about the difficult choices you face and the stresses that you 're under
let 's have paid family leave , earned sick days
Let 's be sure we have affordable child care and debt-free college
How are we going to do it
We 're going to do it by having the wealthy pay their fair share and close the corporate loopholes
we tonight are on the stage together , Donald Trump and I
it 's good to be with you
We 're going to have a debate where we are talking about the important issues facing our country
You have to judge us , who can shoulder the immense , awesome responsibilities of the presidency , who can put into action the plans that will make your life better
I hope that I will be able to earn your vote on November 8th"

cqs.cq: How strong is the generalisation that if a politician prioritizes economic equality and social welfare, they will automatically be able to implement policies that benefit the middle class, rather than just the wealthy?
Is what Clinton said about "having the wealthy pay their fair share and close the corporate loopholes" consistent with known evidence in the domain of economics and taxation?

Are there differences between the promises of Clinton and the actions she took as Secretary of State that would tend to undermine the force of her claim that she will make the wealthy pay their fair share and close corporate loopholes?

Is it practically possible for the wealthy to pay their fair share without increasing taxes on the middle class and small business owners, thereby potentially hindering economic growth and job creation?

id_3.input:
CLINTON: "nine million people lost their jobs
Five million people lost their homes
$ 13 trillion in family wealth was wiped out
Now , we have come back from that abyss
it has not been easy
we 're now on the precipice of having a potentially much better economy
the last thing we need to do is to go back to the policies that failed us in the first place
Independent experts have looked at what I 've proposed
looked at what Donald 's proposed
I intend to get it done
Take clean energy
Some country is going to be the clean- energy superpower of the 21st century
Donald thinks that climate change is a hoax perpetrated by the Chinese
I think it 's real"

cqs.cq: Are there other factors in this particular case that could have interfered with the event of the US economy becoming 'potentially much better' if the policies proposed by Clinton were implemented instead of those proposed by Trump?
Is Donald's claim that climate change is a hoax perpetrated by the Chinese consistent with what other experts in the domain of climate science say?

Are there differences between the economic recovery under Clinton's policies and the economic recovery under Trump's policies that would tend to undermine the force of the similarity cited between Clinton's proposed approach to climate change and the successful economic recovery?

Is it not contradictory for Clinton to claim that the economy is on the precipice of being better after implementing policies that might exacerbate climate change, which she acknowledges as real, considering the devastating economic consequences of ignoring or downplaying this issue in the past?

id_4.input:
CLINTON: "Let 's talk about two important issues that were briefly mentioned by Donald
first , NATO
NATO as a military alliance has something called Article 5
you know the only time it 's ever been invoked ?
After 9/11 , when the 28 nations of NATO said that they would go to Afghanistan with us to fight terrorism
something that they still are doing by our side
With respect to Iran , when I became secretary of state , Iran was weeks away from having enough nuclear material to form a bomb
They had mastered the nuclear fuel cycle under the Bush administration
They had built covert facilities
They had stocked them with centrifuges that were whirling away
we had sanctioned them"

cqs.cq: Are there other factors in this particular case that could have interfered with the event of Iran having a nuclear bomb, given that the US had already acknowledged that Iran had mastered the nuclear fuel cycle and built covert facilities under the Bush administration?

Is CLINTON's statement that Iran was "weeks away from having enough nuclear material to form a bomb" during her tenure as Secretary of State consistent with known evidence in the domain of international relations and nuclear non-proliferation?

Are there differences between the situation with Iran and the situation with NATO in the post-9/11 era that would tend to undermine the force of the similarity cited, given that the former resulted in significant international sanctions and diplomatic isolation for Iran, whereas the latter led to a unified military response with NATO member states?

Is it practically possible for the US and its allies to maintain their involvement in Afghanistan under Article 5 of NATO, considering the prolonged nature of the conflict and the increasing domestic and international pressures to withdraw?

id_5.input:
CLINTON: "I voted for every sanction against Iran when I was in the Senate
it was n't enough
I spent a year-and-a-half putting together a coalition that included Russia and China to impose the toughest sanctions on Iran
 we did drive them to the negotiating table
my successor , John Kerry , and President Obama got a deal that put a lid on Iran 's nuclear program without firing a single shot
That 's diplomacy
That 's coalition-building
That 's working with other nations
That 's not good judgment"

cqs.cq: Are there other factors in this particular case that could have interfered with the event of Iran's willingness to negotiate and possibly agree to a deal, considering Clinton's claim that her diplomatic efforts were the primary cause of their willingness to negotiate?

Is what Clinton claims about her role in driving Iran to the negotiating table and securing a deal without firing a shot consistent with known evidence in the domain of international relations and diplomacy?

Are there differences between Clinton's actions in Iran and the current situation in Ukraine that would tend to undermine the force of the similarity cited between her ability to drive Iran to the negotiating table through sanctions and her ability to handle the current crisis with Russia?
Is it bad that the sanctions imposed on Iran ultimately led to a nuclear deal, as it might be argued that the deal itself was not as effective as the sanctions in preventing Iran's nuclear program?
